titleStmt.title: Letter, James L. Dodds in France to Ellen Smith in Jackson, Tenn.,1918 Nov. 13

publicationStmt.publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries Digital Initiatives

availability.p: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.

bibl.title: Letter, James L. Dodds in France to Ellen Smith in Jackson, Tenn.,1918 Nov. 13

projectDesc.p: Machine-readable transcription created for the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections.

editorialDecl.p: Errors in transcription of the printed text not controlled.
Editorial tags limited to gap and unclear.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

revisionDesc.change: Approximate date of original transcription and transcriber.
Migrating from P4 to validated TEI P5.

div.p: Will write you a few lines this A.M. I am feeling fine Hope you are fine and dandy I have not heard from you in several days. I have some trouble getting My Mail since I got transferred it goes to L. Co. and then they send it to me.
This is some pretty day of course I have to say some thing about it as we have so few pretty days overhere. I hope will stay this way for a while just to see how I would feel.
I know this will be old news when you get this but just got to tell you the war is over and I am some glad I am not alone either.
last night as to who wanted to see the war end the most I believe Orr won the argument of course we let him have his way.

The next thing I am looking to of interest now is the boat that brings me back to Dear old America. I am afraid wont be soon enough. I dont expect to get home murch sooner than six months from now and this will be the longest time of it all
I guess I will wonder a million times when we will start home Guess you are expecting a good time Christmas
I sure would like to be there and go to some of those dances I know they will have.
But any way you can thank how murch I would like to be there with you I guess I will be having a time all to my self out here some where in the mud with My truck

I can stand most any thing tho when I know will soon be home once again. It is most dinner time and I dont know any news only abut the war being over and you have read all about that so will quit for this time Write me real often
